catalyst.context: CO 2 is highly stable and therefore extremely difficult to be reduced at room temperature even by photocatalysis.Herein, a series of g-C 3 N 4 /Bi 2 WO 6 composites have been synthesized through a facile in situ hydrothermal approach, which demonstrated greatly enhanced response to visible light, and consequently a remarkably enhanced CO 2 selective photoreduction to CO.The g-C 3 N 4 content and synthesis parameters of these composites have been tuned to obtain the optimized photocatalytic activity with a peak CO production rate of 5.19 mmol g A1 h A1 under visible light irradiation at room temperature, which was 22 and 6.4 times that on pure g-C 3 N 4 and Bi 2 WO 6 , respectively.Based on the matched band energy potentials between g-C 3 N 4 and Bi 2 WO 6 in the synthesized composites, a possible Z-scheme mechanism, which features a significantly promoted separation of photo-generated carriers under visible light irradiation by the composites, has been proposed to account for the distinctive CO 2 photoreduction performance.

catalyst.context: All chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received without further purication.Metal-free g-C 3 N 4 was prepared by thermally decomposing urea (Sinapharm Chemical Reagent Corp, PR China) at 550 C in an alumina crucible with a cover for 2 h in static air with a ramp rate of 4 C min A1 .Aer the reaction, the crucible was cooled to room temperature naturally.The resulting yellow product was collected and ground into ne powder for further use. Pure Bi 2 WO 6 was synthesized by a modied hydrothermal method. 51The g-C 3 N 4 /Bi 2 WO 6 photocatalysts were obtained by a hydrothermal method using the above mentioned g-C 3 N 4 and precursors of Bi 2 WO 6 .In a typical procedure, 0.3299 g Na 2 -WO 4 2H 2 O and different amounts of g-C 3 N 4 (from 0.05 g to 0.3 g) were mixed in 50 mL deionized water, followed by an ultrasound treatment for 20 min to obtain a uniform suspension.Meanwhile, 0.9701 g Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O was added to 5 mL 1 M HNO 3 to form a clear solution under stirring at room temperature.The Na 2 WO 4 and g-C 3 N 4 solution was then dropped into Bi(NO 3 ) 3 solution under vigorous stirring.Finally, 2 mL of oleyl amine (C 18 H 37 N) and 270 mL of NH 3 2H 2 O were added into the above mixed solution.The obtained mixed solution was then placed in a 100 mL Teon-lined autoclave.The resulting samples were collected by centrifugation, washed several times with cyclohexane and deionized water and lyophilized overnight.According to this method, a series of g-C 3 N 4 /Bi 2 WO 6 photocatalysts with various mass ratios of g-C 3 N 4 to Bi 2 WO 6 were prepared and denoted as g-C 3 N 4 -x/Bi 2 WO 6 , where x refers to the weight of the added g-C 3 N 4 .The inuences of hydrothermal temperature and time on the photocatalytic activity were also investigated. For photocatalyst characterization, the crystallinity of the powders was recorded by a Rigaku D/Max 2200 PC X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with a scanning rate of 4 min A1 .The X-ray tube using Cu Ka radiation was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA.The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specic surface area of the samples was characterized using a Micromeritics Tristar 2000 instrument at 77 K. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, energy dispersive spectra and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were obtained by a JEM-2100F eld emission transmission electron microscope operated at 200 kV.Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images were acquired with a Hitachi S-4800.The UV-visible absorption spectra were recorded in the range of 200-800 nm with a UV-3101 PC Shimadzu spectroscope using BaSO 4 as a reference.A Hitachi F-4500 was used to analyze the catalysts' photoluminescence (PL) characteristics with an excitation wavelength of 370 nm at room temperature.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out with a Thermo Scientic ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with an Al Ka radiation line source.All the binding energies for the high-resolution spectra were calibrated by setting C 1s to 285 eV.Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained with a Nicolet iZ10 FTIR spectrometer at a resolution of 4 cm A1 .A total of 64 scans were performed to obtain each spectrum. Electrochemical measurements were carried out on a CHI 660A electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument, Inc.) with a conventional three-electrode cell.Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) deposited with photocatalysts served as a working electrode, while the counter and the reference electrodes were a platinum wire and Ag/AgCl respectively, with 0.1 M Na 2 SO 4 as electrolyte solution.The working electrodes were prepared by electrophoretic deposition in an acetone solution (15 mL) containing g-C 3 N 4 /Bi 2 WO 6 , Bi 2 WO 6 or g-C 3 N 4 powder (12 mg) and iodine (3 mg). 53The FTO glass was kept in the above solution for 3 min with a 10 V bias under potentiostat control.All the samples are deposited as thin lms onto FTO by electrophoretic deposition.Aer being calcined for 2 h in an oven at 150 C, a homogeneous lm was obtained.50 mL of 0.1 M Na 2 SO 4 was used as electrolyte solution, which represented the best compromise between activity and stability of the composites. During the Mott-Schottky test, a Pt wire and an Ag/AgCl electrode were also used as the counter and reference electrodes respectively.The working electrode was prepared as follows, 54 with an area of about 1 cm 2 .80 mg of Bi 2 WO 6 , 10 mg of carbon black and 10 mg of polyvinylidene uoride binder were mixed in ethanol.Aer being dried in an oven at 80 C overnight, 10 mg of the mixture was pasted onto a nickel foam current collector.Mott-Schottky plots were generated with a frequency of 962 Hz. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was performed in batches by using a reactor (volume: 500 mL) purchased from Perfect-Light Company (Beijing, China).The reactor is made of borosilicate glass, with an optical quartz window at the top, and the distance from the plate to the window is 11 cm.To remove possible trace organic contaminants, all the samples were treated at 200 C for 3 h in air.In a typical process, 0.1 g photocatalyst was uniformly dispersed on a at quartz plate with an area of 4 cm 2 .In order to ensure that air was eliminated, highpurity CO 2 (99.99) gas, monitored by a mass ow controller, was passed through a water bubbler to generate a mixture of CO 2 and water vapor, and then owed through the reactor for about half an hour before the light irradiation.A 300 W xenonarc lamp (Aulight CEL-HX, Beijing) with a 420 nm cutoff lter was used as a light source.The temperature of the reactor was controlled at 25 C by cooling water circulation.The concentration of products in the gas phase was monitored by periodical sampling from the glass chamber by using a gas-tight syringe and 1 mL of the reaction product was taken from the glass chamber at given time intervals (1 h).Each sample was analyzed by GC (Fuli GC-2060) with a ame ionization detector equipped with a 5A molecular column and a TDX-01 packed column to detect hydrocarbons and GC (Techcomp GC-7900) equipped with a thermal conductive detector and a 5A molecular sieve column to detect O 2 and/or H 2 in the outlet gases.CO was detected by installing a methanizer, using N 2 as the carrier gas.During the photostability measurements, the glass setup was purged by high-purity N 2 several times, followed by a mixture of CO 2 and H 2 O vapor in each run.Besides, the effect of H 2 O presence in the photocatalytic system was also studied by using dry CO 2 feed gas and reducing the water molecule adsorption on the sample surface as far as possible.

The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was performed in batches by using a reactor (volume: 500 mL) purchased from Perfect-Light Company (Beijing, China).The reactor is made of borosilicate glass, with an optical quartz window at the top, and the distance from the plate to the window is 11 cm.To remove possible trace organic contaminants, all the samples were treated at 200 C for 3 h in air.In a typical process, 0.1 g photocatalyst was uniformly dispersed on a at quartz plate with an area of 4 cm 2 .In order to ensure that air was eliminated, highpurity CO 2 (99.99) gas, monitored by a mass ow controller, was passed through a water bubbler to generate a mixture of CO 2 and water vapor, and then owed through the reactor for about half an hour before the light irradiation.A 300 W xenonarc lamp (Aulight CEL-HX, Beijing) with a 420 nm cutoff lter was used as a light source.The temperature of the reactor was controlled at 25 C by cooling water circulation.The concentration of products in the gas phase was monitored by periodical sampling from the glass chamber by using a gas-tight syringe and 1 mL of the reaction product was taken from the glass chamber at given time intervals (1 h).Each sample was analyzed by GC (Fuli GC-2060) with a ame ionization detector equipped with a 5A molecular column and a TDX-01 packed column to detect hydrocarbons and GC (Techcomp GC-7900) equipped with a thermal conductive detector and a 5A molecular sieve column to detect O 2 and/or H 2 in the outlet gases.CO was detected by installing a methanizer, using N 2 as the carrier gas.During the photostability measurements, the glass setup was purged by high-purity N 2 several times, followed by a mixture of CO 2 and H 2 O vapor in each run.Besides, the effect of H 2 O presence in the photocatalytic system was also studied by using dry CO 2 feed gas and reducing the water molecule adsorption on the sample surface as far as possible.
